section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that today we will review the letters Xx and Zz.
Sing the alphabet together. Have children stand up when the first letter of their name is sung. Have children raise their hand when the first letter of their last name is sung.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a narrative called The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach.
Look! Pablo is peeking at the pictures to see why this story starts with a caterpillar and ends with a butterfly!
I want you to think about the guiding question while we read. After, we can try to answer it together. Ready?
Why is the caterpillar impatient?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the letter z in the word metamorphosize. Who can come point to the letter z? What sound does the letter z make?
Now we know that metamorphosize means turning into a butterfly. What do you see on this page?
Let’s all stand up. Show me how you twirl!
The impatient caterpillar finally built a chrysalis! What do you think the caterpillars are waiting for now?
The caterpillar learns that being in the chrysalis will take two weeks! How do you think he feels about waiting that long?
The impatient caterpillar tries to fly. What happens?
What does the impatient caterpillar finally become?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
Why is the caterpillar impatient?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, using Equity Sticks, choose two or three pairs of children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The caterpillar doesn’t want to be in a chrysalis.
The caterpillar wants to be a butterfly.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences comparing and contrasting a caterpillar and a butterfly.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the caterpillar want to be a butterfly?
The caterpillar wants to be a b_____ (butterfly).
The caterpillar wants to be a butterfly.
What are the steps in the caterpillar’s metamorphosis?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Metamorphosis is a fascinating introduction to the vast diversity of life on Earth. You will be introducing some children to this concept for the first time. Explain that caterpillars aren’t the only organisms to metamorphosize. Share images of tadpoles turning to frogs. Encourage children to use academic language to describe the steps.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Self-Awareness
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that the caterpillar knows he is impatient and works hard to change. Explain that it’s okay to admit we may not be good at something. Then, we can work to get better at it. Ask children: What do you do when you feel impatient? Allow them to share ideas for managing impatience.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the narrative The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach. This time, let’s talk about the caterpillar’s self-awareness.
Clifford has a hard time waiting for something fun, too. He can’t wait to read about a caterpillar who feels the same way!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The impatient caterpillar tells the other caterpillars, “Wait for me!” Can you think of a time when you wanted someone to wait for you? What did you want to do? (MB)
The caterpillar tells the impatient caterpillar to build a chrysalis. Do you think the impatient caterpillar really knew that it was time to build a chrysalis?
Why does the caterpillar tell the impatient caterpillar to be patient? Has a teacher or a parent ever told you to be patient? How did that make you feel? (MB)
Do you think the caterpillar is being patient? Why?
What are the other chrysalises trying to do?
Why doesn’t the impatient caterpillar have wings yet?
On what day does the impatient caterpillar say, “I CAN be patient”?
Why do you think he says this?

section.rac_body-text: Have children pretend they are in a scenario in which patience is required, such as going on a long car ride or waiting for an exciting holiday. Challenge children to show how they act when they are feeling impatient, and then how they act when they are patient. When all children have had a turn, explain that they showed self-awareness and should feel proud of themselves for knowing how to act patiently—even if it isn’t always easy.
Ask children to share what they are proud of about themselves. Transcribe their speech and allow them to draw their answers, too.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Patience requires self-regulation, which some children develop more easily than others. Self-regulation allows children to manage their feelings in difficult situations. Praise patient behavior in the classroom to sharpen self-awareness. (Parenttoolkit.com/Self-awareness.)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that children can make a smart conclusion by coming up with a new idea using ideas from the book.
Have children crawl in place as a caterpillar, form a chrysalis by sitting in a ball on the floor, and then jump up and flap their wings like a butterfly.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach.
Pablo is excited to reread the narrative. This time, he is going to focus on putting together ideas in the book to make a new idea!
Keep in mind this question as we reread today:
How do we know that the caterpillar is impatient?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children as they use the pictures and text to draw conclusions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the impatient caterpillar ask? How does this question show that the caterpillar is impatient?
What question does the impatient caterpillar ask again? Why does the other caterpillar say “Be patient!”?
Why did the other caterpillar yell at the impatient caterpillar? What text features show you that the caterpillar is yelling?
What is the impatient caterpillar upset about?
Do you think the caterpillar really feels metamorphosized enough on Day 1?
Why does the impatient caterpillar fall right away? What do you think he needs?
Did you think about the question while we reread our book?
How do we know that the caterpillar is impatient?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment to Turn and Talk.Then, choose two or three children to share their answers.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The caterpillar thinks two weeks is a long time.
The caterpillar leaves the chrysalis early.

section.rac_body-text: Work together with children to describe their conclusions. Ask volunteers to share their reasoning. Encourage connected thinking.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the caterpillar leave the chrysalis early?
The caterpillar leaves the chrysalis ear______ (early).
The caterpillar leaves the chrysalis early.
What questions does the impatient caterpillar ask?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Being able to create complex sentences is a great way to increase children’s reading, writing, and speaking skills. As children share their conclusions, help multilingual learners create complex sentences by offering connectors they can use to extend their sentences such as “I think the caterpillar is still impatient because…”

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Praise children for all the growing up they did this year. Talk about new friends and old projects. Instill a sense of pride in their newfound knowledge and hard work.
Celebrate children’s learning by having them act out something they learned from the past year, such as school rules or taking care of Earth.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read the informational poster What We Have Learned. It will remind us of all we’ve learned this year!
Pablo loves looking at the pictures on this poster. He is very proud of all the hard work we have done!
The Very Impatient Caterpillar and What We Have Learned are about learning new things. Let’s see if we can find other connections between the two!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept question for the week: How have we changed?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What sound does the letter M make in the word Me? What sound does the letter e make in the word Me? Let’s put the sounds together!
Name something in your community.
What do you like to investigate?
What is the girl holding? What did we discover about animals?
What is the boy eating? What is your favorite healthy food?
What is this child doing? What do you like to create?
What is the boy holding? How can we recycle?
Why is it important to work together?

section.rac_body-text: Have children self-assess how they have changed. Direct children to draw a picture of themselves doing something they learned to do this year. Encourage children to share their drawings and explain them.
Provide a writing prompt about how children have changed, and give feedback as children write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children who are well-versed in emotional literacy are happier, have better relationships, and do better academically over time. Stress their importance while increasing children’s confidence by pointing out how they’ve learned to greet each other, ask to play, manage feelings, and use empathy.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Provide children with scenarios in which patience is required (waiting for a turn on the swings, waiting to be excused from the table, not being allowed to do what older siblings can do). Allow children to act out a reaction. Have other children in the class evaluate the reaction and give a thumbs-up to indicate if the reaction is appropriate. Celebrate children and their excellent practice of patience!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread the story The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach.
Pablo loves this narrative because he can learn from it. He has a hard time waiting sometimes and wants to be more patient!
As we reread the narrative, think about this question:
How are you like the impatient caterpillar?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does the impatient caterpillar seem surprised? What will he transform into?
Let’s pretend to build a chrysalis. Show me how you spin and twirl!
Now let’s pretend to be the rest of the caterpillars and shush the impatient caterpillar. Put your fingers to your lips and say, “Shhh!”
Why is it funny that the impatient caterpillar orders a pizza? Do you think a caterpillar can really order a pizza?
Do you think the impatient caterpillar waited long enough? When was a time that you could not wait any longer?
Let’s practice our patience like the impatient caterpillar. Let’s sit down in our chrysalis. Let’s breathe in and breathe out slowly. How do you feel?
Now let’s pop up! We’re butterflies! Look at our colorful wings!

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How are you like the impatient caterpillar?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about what they think about the caterpillar’s feelings.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why is it important to be patient?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children make connections between a book and their own lives, they can better relate to a character and deepen their understanding of the storyline. It also bolsters reading comprehension. By inviting children to connect to the narrative, teachers help shape empathetic children and invested readers.
